This is how u can make margarine homemade and it is heart healthy

Ingredients:
Olive oil / canola oil
Coconut oil
Squeezed lemon
Turmeric
Garlic

1. Pour in two tablespoons of Olive Oil or canola oil (no vegetable oil or sunflower oil) into beaker
2. Add in a cup of coconut oil
3. Add a pinch of turmeric
4. Add a teaspoon of lemon juice from fresh lemon
5. Add in 2 cloves of gushed garlic
6. Use a blender until the texture is smooth
7. Put it in your freezer and let it sett overnight

Trans fat are horrible for you, but saturated fats ARE NOT BAD. They can raise cholesterol, but unless your cholesterol levels are high, do not lower your intake of saturated fat. This fats is a catalyst for absorbing calcium into your bones, cell membranes are made of saturated fat and you do not want to weaken your cells by depriving them of something they need. Humans have been eating full fat dairy products for thousands of years, and they were not dropping dead from heart attacks caused by high cholesterol. In a study when subjects were given vegetable oil and the other group was given dairy products and meat, things did not go as far you would expect. The ones that ate vegetable oils in place of dairy and saturated fat, their cholesterol levels dropped too low, to the point where it increased their chance of death by 20% to 30%! Also, omega 6 polyunsaturated fat is toured in cells when your body has too much to use as fuel, and when the polyunsaturated fats are stored into your cells and make your cells irritable to oxidizing, which is really bad. Yeah, unsaturated fats can be an oxidant. Unsaturated are vital for a healthy diet, but so are saturated fats, do not try and have excessive amounts of either, because yes saturated fat can be bad in excessive amounts like unsaturated fats. And yes, saturated fat can raise cholesterol, but like I said, do not worry about cholesterol, unless you have abnormally high cholesterol. Have each in normal amounts, and you will be very healthy. Don't try and replace one with the other. It is called a balanced diet.

Margarine was originally manufactured to fatten turkeys. When it killed the turkeys, the people who had put all the money into the research wanted a payback so they put their heads together to figure out what to do with this product to get their money back.

It was a white substance with no food appeal so they added the yellow coloring and sold it to people to use in place of butter. How do you like it? They have come out with some clever new flavorings....

DO YOU KNOW.. The difference between margarine and butter?

Read on to the end...gets very interesting!

Both have the same amount of calories.

Butter is slightly higher in saturated fats at 8 grams; compared to 5 grams for margarine.

Eating margarine can increase heart disease in women by 53% over eating the same amount of butter, according to a recent Harvard Medical Study.

Eating butter increases the absorption of many other nutrients in other foods.

Butter has many nutritional benefits where margarine has a few and only because they are added!

Butter tastes much better than margarine and it can enhance the flavors of other foods.

Butter has been around for centuries where margarine has been around for less than 100 years .

And now, for Margarine..

Very High in Trans fatty acids.

Triples risk of coronary heart disease ...

Increases total cholesterol and LDL (this is the bad cholesterol) and lowers HDL cholesterol, (the good cholesterol)

Increases the risk of cancers up to five times..

Lowers quality of breast milk

Decreases immune response.

Decreases insulin response.

And here's the most disturbing fact... HERE IS THE PART THAT IS VERY INTERESTING!

Margarine is but ONE MOLECULE away from being PLASTIC... and shares 27 ingredients with PAINT.

These facts alone were enough to have me avoiding margarine for life and anything else that is hydrogenated (this means hydrogen is added, changing the molecular structure of the substance).

Open a tub of margarine and leave it open in your garage or shaded area. Within a couple of days you will notice a couple of things:

* no flies, not even those pesky fruit flies will go near it (that should tell you something)

* it does not rot or smell differently because it has no nutritional value ; nothing will grow on it. Even those teeny weeny microorganisms will not a find a home to grow.

Why? Because it is nearly plastic . Would you melt your Tupperware and spread that on your toast?

I don't think it's fair to say that butter is natural while margarine isn't.  Butter does not exist in nature.  Cows don't give butter.  Admittedly, the processing is purely mechanical, but it is a processed food.  Margarine is processed mechanically and with heat, but it doesn't require poison or anything to make it.  Almost everything we eat is eventually processed with heat on our stove tops, so it's not really a negative.  I'm not advocating for margarine, though, neither is really a replacement for the other.  You can't really bake with margarine, and if you are on a low-cholesterol diet, you should be avoiding butter.

Interesting but how do they make margarine today?
"While butter that cows produced had a slightly yellow color, margarine had a white color, making the margarine look more like lard. Many people found it to look unappetizing. Around the late 1880s the manufacturers decided to dye the margarine yellow, so it would sell more. Dairy firms, especially in Wisconsin, became alarmed and succeeded in getting legislation passed to prohibit the coloring of the stark white product. In response, the margarine companies distributed the margarine together with a packet of yellow dye. In 1951 the W. E. Dennison Company received U.S. Patent 2,553,513 for a method to place a capsule of yellow dye inside a plastic package of margarine.
During WWII rationing, only two types of margarine were available in the UK, a premium brand and a cheaper budget brand. In recent decades, margarine spreads have gone through many developments in efforts to improve their healthfulness. Most brands have phased out the use of hydrogenated oils, and are now also trans fat free. Many brands have launched refrigerator-stable margarine spreads that contain only 1/3 of the fat and calorie content of traditional spreads. Other varieties of spreads include those with added Omega-3 fatty acids, those with low or no salt, those with added plant sterols, claimed to reduce blood cholesterol, and some made from olive oil or certified vegan oils.
Commonly, the natural oils are hydrogenated by passing hydrogen through the oil in the presence of a nickel catalyst, under controlled conditions. The addition of hydrogen to the unsaturated bonds (alkenic double C=C bonds) results in saturated C-C bonds, effectively increasing the melting point of the oil and thus "hardening" it.. This method is used today for some margarines although the process has been developed and sometimes other metal catalysts are used such as palladium. If hydrogenation is incomplete (partial hardening), the relatively high temperatures used in the hydrogenation process tend to flip some of the carbon-carbon double bonds into the "trans" form. If these particular bonds aren't hydrogenated during the process, they remain present in the final margarine in molecules of trans fats, the consumption of which has been shown to be a risk factor for cardiovascular disease.
If no solid fats are added to the vegetable oils, the latter undergo a full or partial hydrogenation process to solidify them. The resulting blend is mixed with water, citric acid, carotenoids, vitamins and milk powder. Emulsifiers such as lecithin help disperse the water phase evenly throughout the oil, and salt and preservatives are also commonly added. This oil-and-water emulsion is then heated, blended, and cooled. The softer tub margarines are made with less hydrogenated, more liquid, oils than block margarines.
Margarine, particularly polyunsaturated margarine, has become a major part of the Western diet and had overtaken butter in popularity in the mid-20th century. In the United States, for example, in 1930, the average person ate over 18 lb (8.2 kg) of butter a year and just over 2 lb (0.91 kg) of margarine. By the end of the 20th century, an average American ate around 5 lb (2.3 kg) of butter and nearly 8 lb (3.6 kg) of margarine.
Margarine has a particular market value to those who observe the Jewish dietary laws of Kashrut, which forbids the mixing of meat and dairy products, hence there are strictly Kosher non-dairy margarines available. These are often used by the Kosher consumer to adapt recipes that use meat and butter or in baked goods served with meat meals. The 2008 Passover margarine shortage in America caused much consternation within the Kosher-observant community." See Wiki "Margarine, by contrast, has always been much worse for you than its profit-grabbing manufacturers have ever been prepared to admit. In the early days, it was made with 'hydrogenated fats', which were so dense that solid concrete couldn't have done a better job of blocking your coronary arteries. Honestly, this stuff was lethal. Confronted with irrefutable ¬evidence, the food-processing giants reluctantly went back to their laboratories and reformulated their product. This time, they boasted, ¬margarine would be made with 'interesterified' vegetable oils (a treatment that re¬arranges the fat molecules under high temperature and pressure, using enzymes or acids as catalysts). It made the oils less dense and therefore, they hoped, less ¬damaging to our health. Why we should believe the manufacturers a second time around I haven't a clue — especially as they never took responsibility for the tremendous damage they had done to global health with their hydrogenated fats — which are now banned in parts of the U.S. because of the concerns about the effects they have on our health. The best part of 20 years on, the components of margarine, or 'spreads' as food processors prefer to call them, may have changed, but the arguments over their impact on health have not. Take the so-called cholesterol-busting spreads such as Benecol and Flora ProActiv. Yes, they use plant chemicals — sterols and stanols — to reduce cholesterol ¬levels, but they do so at a time when long-held beliefs on cholesterol are beginning to look as shaky as those about saturated fats."See http://www.dailymail.co.uk/health/article-2274747/At-truth-Butter-GOOD--margarine-chemical-gunk.htmlHowever I would recommend butter made from organic farming. Butter (real butter from grass-fed cows) is NOT fattening. In fact, the many properties of butter make it a very slimming food, including its content of all the fat-soluble vitamins (especially if it is raw and grass-fed), as well as all of the fats that are necessary for proper absorption/assimilation of these vitamins, which means that yes, saturated fat is actually good for you if it is in the context of a natural animal fat. It's very interesting to me that the makers of this video didn't bother fact-checking the lipid hypothesis of heart disease, which is wrought with manipulated data and only correlative associations (that are based off of the manipulated data). The fact is that there is literally zero evidence to suggest that the structure of saturated fat, which is not solid in your body since it melts as soon as it hits your tongue, damages arteries, in fact, it is protective of the heart. There is a good layer of saturated fat surrounding the heart to be used as energy in times of crisis. The surfactant of the lungs is made up of entirely saturated fat. You cannot avoid saturated fat. If you do not consume it, your body is going to use whatever it can to make them (i.e. excess carbohydrates). They make up 50% of the phospholipid portion of cell membranes and give good integrity to each cell. Trans fats found in margarine, however, are beyond unnatural. There is no single food product out there that will clog your arteries faster. Why? The oil itself does not behave in the same way that saturated fat does in the body and is actually turns rancid during processing, acting as a free radical that does indeed damage whatever it comes into contact with, which includes the endothelium (lining of arteries). It is a completely unnatural product. Butter has been eaten for thousands of years, and if it is as toxic as it supposedly is, why are we all here? Wouldn't it have given everybody heart disease? Nope. Refined carbohydrates and an avoidance of animal products did that. Try eating grass-fed butter with your meals and notice the difference in satiety and fullness that you feel. There's a reason why we all want to put it on everything, it is thoroughly nourishing!

There are also a whole variety of in between products, ranging from the likes of ICBINB, which is margarine with a bit of buttermilk added to improve the taste; to "spreadable" butters which are typically 75% butter and 25% vegetable oil, but may dilute the mixture with water to form a "light" spread (however, the still large quantity of butter means they don't need to add emulsifiers, colours or any other gunk).

Increasingly, the more solid spreads are made with palm oil, which is semi-solid to begin with so doesn't require hydrogenation. However, (a) they still add a lot of gunk to the mixture, (b) palm groves are often found on land cleared of rainforest, so unsurprisingly support far less wildlife than the native trees.

Meanwhile, about the only treatment done to butter is to pasteurise the milk beforehand and add salt (although it is now possible to buy unsalted butter).

Essentially, although you’re consuming a product with a lot of calcium in it (i.e. milk), your body can't absorb it and has to actually sap calcium from your bones in order to digest it. Cue osteoporosis and calcium deficiency, among other things. Calcium from leafy greens (such as kale and spinach), nuts (almonds, Brazil nuts), sesame seeds and flax seeds, however, is efficiently absorbed by the body.

Upon consumption, animal derived protein-rich food (such as milk and meat) acidifies pH. This excess acid promotes the formation of kidney stones and poses a danger to the kidneys and urinary tract. In order to protect the latter, the human body tries to neutralize the acid by leaching alkaline minerals (potassium, magnesium and, indeed, calcium) from the bones. Once pulled from the bones (in order to deal with the repercussions from the consumed milk), calcium gets excreted via urine.

Activation energy of hydrogenation is quite high (C=C bond energy is about 260kJ and H-H bond is about 440kJ), so usually a catalyst such as nickel is used, and the reaction is held at higher temperature.  The overlap of the bond pair in H-H with the d-orbitals in Nickel fills the sigma* (antibonding) orbital in H-H, which weakens the bond.  Likewise, the co-ordination of the C=C bond with Ni also weakens the pi bond in the alkene by filling the pi* orbital. Thus, activation energy is lowered.
That makes perfect sense, thank you!

If a reaction is exothermic, it means the products are favoured.  Given enough time the reaction will proceed at room temperature, albeit very slowly.  Heating increases the rate of reaction so that the hydrogenation can be done faster.  Usually once the reactants are heated and the rate of reaction increases, the energy released from the reaction should keep the reactor hot, so yes, heating triggers the process.

Actually fat doesn't clog veins - what you're thinking of is hardening of the arteries. Atherosclerosis (hardening of the arteries) is actually caused by inflammation of the arterial wall. Cholesterol and fats are attracted to the point of inflammation to help fix it, like how platelets attract at a cut, forming a hard plaque beneath the arterial wall. However if the arteries are constantly inflamed, plaques grow and eventually burst, causing a clot of form and cause a heart attack.

Saturated fat is, because of the higher melting point, more likely than unsaturated fat to clog your veins. However, if you limit (rather than eliminate) your intake, it is not the worst kind of fat you can eat. As said in the video, trans fatty acids are much worse.

Margarine that is marketed as having no trans fat usually DOES have trans fats. Anything under 0.5 g gets to be counted as 0g on the nutrition label. So if you have several servings, then the amount of trans fats that you ingest really adds up. Also, the fat on the nutrition label only reflects triglycerides. You often see in the ingredients list "mono- and di- glycerides." Those mono and diglycerides could be trans fatty acids and you'd never know.

@Sara Zerof The female has *two* X chromosomes so one can override the other if on X chromosome has the gene. It is very rare to get to X chromosomes with colorblindness. It's called 9th grade Biology, you should take it sometime, idiot.

@Sara Zerof To put it simply: Color blindness is caused by a mutation in the sex chromosome (23rd) of a female. It is very rare to see color blind females because they contain to X chromosomes (color-blindness is recessive) and so they are a carrier for the trait. Males however contain a single X and a single Y chromosome so there is nothing to override the mutation on on the X chromosome therefore colorblindness is shown. A male cannot pass it on to a SON only a daughter.

because calories are derived from fats but fats are essential to our diet. Fats (also known as lipids), carbohydrates, and proteins are the three ways in which we get energy from food. Because one of the features that increases in size relative to body size during puberty is the larynx or voice box. Hey MrNewboysfan,

Brain freezes are caused by rapid temperature changes in your mouth causing the blood vessels of your palate to quickly constrict and dilate. This vasoconstriction and vasodilation is interpreted by your nervous system as pain. The signal is then carried through your Trigeminal nerve to your brain. This is a major nerve which supplies sensation to much of your face. (Which is why you feel a brain freeze in your forehead.)  For more cool science, check out my channel!
